\( \def\curl#1{\text{curl }#1} \def\bracket#1{\left({#1}\right)} \def\sbracket#1{\left[{#1}\right]} %square bracket \def\cbracket#1{\left\{{#1}\right\}} %curly bracket \def\Lim_#1{{\lim\limits_{#1}}} \def\limit{{\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}}} \def\dsum{{\displaystyle \sum}} \def\Sum_#1^#2{{\sum\limits_{#1}^#2}} \def\summ{\sum\limits_{n=0}^{\infty}} \def\R{{\mathbb R}} \def\N{{\mathbb N}} \def\fQ{{\mathcal{Q}}} \def\riemannR{{\mathscr{R}}} \def\ep{\varepsilon} \def\d{\displaystyle} \def\grad{\nabla} \def\q{q} \def\mod#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\abs#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\crossProduct#1{\left\|\begin{array}{ccc} #1 \end{array}\right\|} \newcommand{\partialwrt}[2][]{\frac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \newcommand{\dpartialwrt}[2][]{\dfrac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \def\upint{\mkern3mu\overline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-20mu\int} \def\lowint{\mkern3mu\underline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-10mu\int} \def\lowsup_#1{_{{\lower{0.3em}{#1}}}} \)

  • 7.01

Pointwise Convergenece

Suppose $\{f_n\}, n=1,2,3...$ is a sequence of functions defined on a set $E$ and suppose that the sequence of numbers $\{f_n(x)\}$ converges for every $x\in E$. We can then define a function $f$ by $$f(x)=\lim_{n \to \infty}f_n(x) \ \ \ (x \in E)$$

Then $\{f_n\}$ converges to $f$ pointwise on $E$ and $f$ is called the limit or limit function of $\{f_n\}$

$f_n(x)=nx$ for all $x \ \in \R$
$$\begin{align*} \text{For all } x \ &\in \R \\ \lim_{n \to \infty}f_n(x) &= \lim_{n \to \infty} nx \to \infty \end{align*}$$

Hence $\{f_n\}$ is not pointwise convergent.

$f_n(x)=\dfrac{nx+x^2}{n^2}$ for all $x \ \in \R$
$$\begin{align*} \text{For all } x \ &\in \R \\ \lim_{n \to \infty}f_n(x) &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{nx+x^2}{n^2} \\ &= \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{x}{n}+\frac{x^2}{n^2} \\ &= 0 + 0 \\\ &= 0 \end{align*}$$

$\{f_n\}$ converges pointwise.

$f_n(x)=\dfrac{\sin(nx+3)}{\sqrt{n+1}}$ for all $x \in \R$

For every $x \in \R$, we have

-1 & \leq & \sin(nx+3) & \leq & 1 \\ \frac{-1}{\sqrt{n+1}} & \leq & \frac{\sin(nx+3)}{\sqrt{n+1}} & \leq & \frac{1}{\sqrt{n+1}} \\ \Lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{-1}{\sqrt{n+1}} & \leq &\Lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{\sin(nx+3)}{\sqrt{n+1}} & \leq & \Lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n+1}} \\ 0 & \leq & \Lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x) & \leq & 0

Since $\Lim_{n\to \infty}f_n(x) = 0$ for all $x$ in $\R$, $\{f_n\}$ converges pointwise.

$f(x)=n^2x^n$ for $0 \leq x \leq 1$s
$$\begin{align*} &\text{For } x=0, & f_n(0) &= 0 \\ &\text{For } 0 < x < 1, & \Lim_{n\to \infty}f_n(x) &= \Lim_{n\to \infty} n^2 x^n \\ &&&= \Lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2}{x^{-n}} \bracket{\text{indeterminate form} \frac{\infty}{\infty}} \\ &&&= \Lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n}{-\ln{x} x^{-n}} \bracket{\text{indeterminate form} \frac{\infty}{\infty}} \\ &&&= \Lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2}{(\ln{x})^2 x^{-n}} \\ &&&= \Lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2x^n}{(\ln{x})^2} \\ &&&= 0 \ (\because 0 < x < 1)\\ &\text{For } x=1, & f_n(1) &= n^2 \\ && \Lim_{n\to \infty} f_n(1) &= \Lim_{n \to \infty} n^2 \to \infty \end{align*}$$

Therefore the sequence $\{f_n(1)\}$ does not converges and hence $\{f_n\}$ does not pointwise converge
